The Beatles recorded this song on 11th February 1963 in ten takes. The tenth one was chosen as the finest, and John Lennon then overdubbed three takes of his one-bar harmonica solo onto it.

This song is notable for it’s brevity and drive. Every section is incredibly short and leaves no room for breath before launching into the next one. George Harrison even joins in on vocals at the end of the verses to hammer the impact home. It would have been an impressive number to have seen live in their raw cavern club days.

This is one of the first occurrences of the famous Aeolian cadence in Lennon-McCartney’s work. This is a musical term describing when the composer chooses to end a section with a minor sixth chord (in this case C#m) instead of the I chord (in this case E) that’d sound natural to the human brain. This creates a dissonant tone that makes the song almost sound as if it’s pining for the next chord.

It also appears most famously in the bridge of Lennon-McCartney’s From Me To You.

The most crazy thing about all this is that Lennon-McCartney had no idea they were employing such expert music theory in their writing. It came completely naturally to them. Lennon hadn’t even heard of the Aeolian cadence when it was brought up in an interview:

“I have no idea what aeolian cadences are. They sound like exotic birds.”

The most striking feature of There’s A Place is the vocal melody. It is unconventional for a pop number of the time, featuring lengthy stretches where it drags an in-key melody over out-of-key chords. The reason the vocals and chords still don’t clash is because the dissonant chords they choose (such as G# and F#) don’t directly contradict the vocal melody.

This is a textbook Lennon melodic trope, and creates his inimitable abrasive singing tone. He drags a dissonant vocal melody through to the next chord on “and there’s no time…” and then chooses to mix up the chord he lands on. A similar technique is heard in Help!’s verses.

Paul McCartney described There’s A Place as one of their more mature early numbers.

In our case the place was in the mind, rather than round the back of the stairs for a kiss and a cuddle. This was the difference with what we were writing: we were getting a bit more cerebral.

It was composed by the pair at Paul’s home, 20 Forthlin Road, as many of their early songs were.

Lennon said of this song in All We Are Saying:

There’s A Place was my attempt at a sort of Motown, black thing. It says the usual Lennon things: ‘In my mind there’s no sorrow…’ It’s all in your mind.
